The Implications of State Aggregation in Deteriorating Markov Decision Processes with Optimal Threshold Policies

Madeleine Pollack Massachusetts Institute of Technology
{pollack9}@mit.edu Lauren N. Steimle Georgia Institute of Technology
{steimle}@gatech.edu
(May 24, 2024)
Abstract

Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) are mathematical models of sequential decision-making under uncertainty that have found applications in healthcare, manufacturing, logistics, and others. In these models, a decision-maker observes the state of a stochastic process and determines which action to take with the goal of maximizing the expected total discounted rewards received. In many applications, the state space of the true system is large and there may be limited observations out of certain states to estimate the transition probability matrix. To overcome this, modelers will aggregate the true states into “superstates” resulting in a smaller state space. This aggregation process improves computational tractability and increases the number of observations among superstates. Thus, the modeler’s choice of state space leads to a trade-off in transition probability estimates. While coarser discretization of the state space gives more observations in each state to estimate the transition probability matrix, this comes at the cost of precision in the state characterization and resulting policy recommendations. In this paper, we consider the implications of this modeling decision on the resulting policies from MDPs for which the true model is expected to have a threshold policy that is optimal. We analyze these MDPs and provide conditions under which the aggregated MDP will also have an optimal threshold policy. Using a simulation study, we explore the trade-offs between more fine and more coarse aggregation. We explore the the show that there is the highest potential for policy improvement on larger state spaces, but that aggregated MDPs are preferable under limited data. We discuss how these findings the implications of our findings for modelers who must select which state space design to use.

Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) are mathematical models of sequential decision-making under uncertainty that have found applications in healthcare, manufacturing, logistics, and others. In these models, a decision-maker observes the state of a stochastic process and determines which action to take with the goal of maximizing the expected total discounted rewards received. In many applications, the state space of the true system is large and there may be limited observations out of certain states to estimate the transition probability matrix. To overcome this, modelers will aggregate the true states into “superstates” resulting in a smaller state space. This aggregation process improves computational tractability and increases the number of observations among superstates. Thus, the modeler’s choice of state space leads to a trade-off in transition probability estimates. While coarser discretization of the state space gives more observations in each state to estimate the transition probability matrix, this comes at the cost of precision in the state characterization and resulting policy recommendations. In this paper, we consider the implications of this modeling decision on the resulting policies from MDPs for which the true model is expected to have a threshold policy that is optimal. We analyze these MDPs and provide conditions under which the aggregated MDP will also have an optimal threshold policy. Using a simulation study, we explore the trade-offs between more fine and more coarse aggregation. We explore the the show that there is the highest potential for policy improvement on larger state spaces, but that aggregated MDPs are preferable under limited data. We discuss how these findings the implications of our findings for modelers who must select which state space design to use.

1 Background

In this section, we describe discrete-time infinite-horizon MDPs and explain the method for deriving the estimated TPM for a given MDP model of this type. We also give an introduction on how to aggregate the state space of a Markov chain or MDP model.

1.1 Markov decision processes

A Markov decision process (MDP) is a model of a stochastic control process in which the DM seeks to take actions to control a stochastic system. The DM observes the system at discrete time points, 𝒯={0,1,2,3,…}𝒯0123…\mathcal{T}=\{0,1,2,3,\ldots\}caligraphic_T = { 0 , 1 , 2 , 3 , … } where t∈𝒯𝑡𝒯t\in\mathcal{T}italic_t ∈ caligraphic_T represents the decision epoch or amount of time (e.g., months, years, etc.) that has passed since the beginning of the planning horizon. In this article, we focus on infinite-horizon MDP models with a countably infinite number of decision epochs. At each decision epoch, the health state, or simply, state of the system h∈𝒮ℎ𝒮h\in\mathcal{S}italic_h ∈ caligraphic_S is observed, where the state space, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, is the set of all possible states. After observing the state of the system, the DM takes some action a∈𝒜𝑎𝒜a\in\mathcal{A}italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A, where the action space, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, is the set of all possible actions. Once this action a𝑎aitalic_a is taken, the DM receives a real-valued reward r⁢(h,a)𝑟ℎ𝑎r(h,a)italic_r ( italic_h , italic_a ). The |𝒮|×|𝒜|𝒮𝒜|\mathcal{S}|\times|\mathcal{A}|| caligraphic_S | × | caligraphic_A | reward matrix ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R contains all possible rewards. Rewards are discounted at a rate of α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) to reflect that rewards received in the future are worth less than those received in the present. Given the current state hℎhitalic_h and the action a𝑎aitalic_a, the conditional probability ph⁢h′a∈[0,1]superscriptsubscript𝑝ℎsuperscriptℎ′𝑎01p_{hh^{\prime}}^{a}\in[0,1]italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], often denoted in other literature as P⁢(h′|h,a)𝑃conditionalsuperscriptℎ′ℎ𝑎P(h^{\prime}\,|\,h,a)italic_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_h , italic_a ), describes the likelihood that the system transitions to a new state h′∈𝒮superscriptℎ′𝒮h^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S in the next decision epoch. The |𝒮|×|𝒮|×|𝒜|𝒮𝒮𝒜|\mathcal{S}|\times|\mathcal{S}|\times|\mathcal{A}|| caligraphic_S | × | caligraphic_S | × | caligraphic_A | matrix describing the stochastic progression of the system makes up the TPM, denoted by P𝑃Pitalic_P. We will exclusively consider stationary rewards and transition probabilities, which means that the rewards and transition probabilities are dependent only on the state and action and not on the decision epoch.

The goal of the DM is to determine the policy that maximizes the expected value of (1). Because the rewards and transition probabilities are stationary, there will exist an optimal policy that is stationary (i.e., independent of time) and deterministic (i.e. the optimal policy maps each state in the vector to a single optimal action with probability 1) [1, Theorem 6.2.10].

Policy iteration, value iteration, and linear programming are common methods of solving (2) and subsequently (3) [1].

1.2 Special MDPs of Interest: Optimal Stopping Time Problems

In this work, we focus on Markov decision processes (MDPs) with two main characteristics. The first characteristic is MDPs with transition probability matrices (TPMs) that are deteriorating. This is often called the Decreasing Failure Rate (DFR) property if the state space is ordered from the least desirable states to the most desirable states. In this paper, our state spaces are ordered such that the DFR property holds to remain consistent with the experiments performed by [2]. Formally, we can define the DFR property as follows.

Definition 1 (Decreasing Failure Rate Property [2])

Pasuperscript𝑃𝑎P^{a}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is said to have the DFR
property if its rows are in decreasing stochastic order. That is, Pasuperscript𝑃𝑎P^{a}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with state space 𝒮J={0,1,2,…,J}subscript𝒮𝐽012…𝐽\mathcal{S}_{J}=\{0,1,2,\ldots,J\}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { 0 , 1 , 2 , … , italic_J } is DFR if ∑j=0npi⁢jasuperscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑗𝑎\sum_{j=0}^{n}p_{ij}^{a}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is nonincreasing in i𝑖iitalic_i for all n∈{0,…,J}𝑛0…𝐽n\in\{0,\ldots,J\}italic_n ∈ { 0 , … , italic_J }.

Deteriorating TPMs are common for application areas like chronic disease progressions [3] and probabilities of equipment failures [4].

The second characteristic of interest is MDPs whose optimal policies are threshold policies. This often arises in stopping time problems with a deteriorating Markov chain and action space {a1,a2}subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2\{a_{1},\;a_{2}\}{ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } where a1subscript𝑎1a_{1}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the “do-nothing” action, and a2subscript𝑎2a_{2}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the “intervention” action that stops the process. Under certain conditions on the TPM and rewards matrix [1, §6.11.2], there is guaranteed to exist an optimal policy that is a threshold policy (also referred to as a control-limit policy), defined as follows.

Definition 2 (Threshold policy )

Given an MDP with ordered state space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S and action space 𝒜={a1,a2}𝒜subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2\mathcal{A}=\{a_{1},a_{2}\}caligraphic_A = { italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, a threshold policy with threshold h∗superscriptℎh^{*}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a deterministic Markov policy with an optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the form

π∗⁢(h)={a1if ⁢h≤h∗a2if ⁢h>h∗.superscript𝜋ℎcasessubscript𝑎1if ℎsuperscriptℎsubscript𝑎2if ℎsuperscriptℎ\pi^{*}(h)=\begin{cases}a_{1}\quad&\text{if }h\leq h^{*}\\ a_{2}\quad&\text{if }h>h^{*}.\\ \end{cases}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL if italic_h ≤ italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL if italic_h > italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW

Threshold policies are often assumed to be optimal in MDPs with deteriorating TPMs because of the intuitive natures of these policies (e.g., in medical decision-making, once a patient reaches a critical level of health, he or she is more likely to continue to deteriorate, so we should initiate treatment). Furthermore, threshold policies are highly interpretable and easily implementable, which makes them attractive to decision makers (DMs).

2 The Implications of State Aggregation on MDPs

In this section, we formalize the state aggregation process and analyze the properties of aggregated MDPs. State aggregation is the process of reducing the state space size by aggregating similar states according to a rule. For ordered state spaces, similar states are typically defined as some number of consecutive states on the ordered state space. An example of an optimal stopping time problem with state aggregation is shown in Figure 1. A valid aggregation of the states into superstates is defined below:

2.1 Aggregating transition probability matrices and rewards

In general, for most TPMs, state aggregation leads to the loss of the Markov property [5]; however, this does not preclude the utility of an MDP as the best (e.g., most interpretable, leading to the lowest regret, etc.) model for a given scenario. Because this paper is meant to consider the utility of an MDP for an applied case study, we see the loss of the Markov property as being noteworthy, but not in direct contradiction to the goals of this paper.

2.3 The effects of aggregation policies in optimal stopping time MDPs

Due to the conservation of state-ordering in our state aggregation function s𝑠sitalic_s, we can observe similarities between the properties of Pasuperscript𝑃𝑎P^{a}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Qasuperscript𝑄𝑎Q^{a}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proposition 1

If s:𝒮J↦𝒮K:𝑠maps-tosubscript𝒮𝐽subscript𝒮𝐾s:\mathcal{S}_{J}\mapsto\mathcal{S}_{K}italic_s : caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ↦ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a valid state aggregation function, then TPM Pasuperscript𝑃𝑎P^{a}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT having the DFR property implies that the aggregated TPM Qasuperscript𝑄𝑎Q^{a}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also has the DFR property.

We will defer this proof and all others to Appendix D. Proposition 1 will become useful when we consider how the structure of unaggregated optimal policies relates to the structure of aggregated optimal policies.

Consider an MDP with action space 𝒜={0,1}𝒜01\mathcal{A}=\{0,1\}caligraphic_A = { 0 , 1 } where 0 is the “do-nothing” action and 1 is the “intervene” action. There are sufficient conditions that guarantee the existence of an optimal policy that is a threshold policy [3]. If we have an unaggregated MDP that meets these criteria, we can guarantee the following.

Proposition 2

Given an unaggregated MDP (𝒮J,𝒜,P,ℛ)subscript𝒮𝐽𝒜𝑃ℛ(\mathcal{S}_{J},\mathcal{A},P,\mathcal{R})( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , italic_P , caligraphic_R ) that satisfies the necessary conditions given by [3] to guarantee a threshold policy and a state aggregation function which generates superstates {1,…,K}1…𝐾\{1,\ldots,K\}{ 1 , … , italic_K } such that for all k=2,3,…,K−1,K𝑘23…𝐾1𝐾k=2,3,\ldots,K-1,Kitalic_k = 2 , 3 , … , italic_K - 1 , italic_K, we have that |Lk−1|=|Lk|subscript𝐿𝑘1subscript𝐿𝑘|L_{k-1}|=|L_{k}|| italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = | italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | and rQ⁢(k, 1)−rQ⁢(k−1, 1)rQ⁢(k,1)≤r⁢(min⁡(Lk), 1)−r⁢(max⁡(Lk−1), 1)r⁢(min⁡(Lk), 1)subscript𝑟𝑄𝑘1subscript𝑟𝑄𝑘11subscript𝑟𝑄𝑘1𝑟subscript𝐿𝑘1𝑟subscript𝐿𝑘11𝑟subscript𝐿𝑘1\frac{r_{Q}(k,\,1)-r_{Q}(k-1,\,1)}{r_{Q}(k\,,1)}\leq\frac{r(\min(L_{k}),\,1)-r% (\max(L_{k-1}),\,1)}{r(\min(L_{k}),\,1)}divide start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k , 1 ) - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 , 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k , 1 ) end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG italic_r ( roman_min ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 1 ) - italic_r ( roman_max ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_r ( roman_min ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 1 ) end_ARG, the corresponding aggregated MDP (𝒮K,A,QK,RQK)subscript𝒮𝐾𝐴subscript𝑄𝐾subscript𝑅subscript𝑄𝐾(\mathcal{S}_{K},A,Q_{K},R_{Q_{K}})( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is guaranteed a threshold policy that is optimal.

Thus, under certain conditions, we show that if the unaggregated model has a threshold policy, we also expect aggregated models to have a threshold policy. Note that the converse does not hold in general.

We now compare the ground truth model to the model estimated from data. Even if a “ground truth” MDP given by (𝒮J,𝒜,P,ℛ)subscript𝒮𝐽𝒜𝑃ℛ(\mathcal{S}_{J},\mathcal{A},P,\mathcal{R})( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , italic_P , caligraphic_R ) is guaranteed a threshold policy, its estimated MDP given by (𝒮J,𝒜,P^,ℛ)subscript𝒮𝐽𝒜^𝑃ℛ(\mathcal{S}_{J},\mathcal{A},\hat{P},\mathcal{R})( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG , caligraphic_R ) is not guaranteed to have a threshold policy due to statistical error causing the sufficient conditions for a threshold policy to not hold. Solving a model with statistical error may result in a policy that has what we refer to as a gray area or a region of the state space where the optimal policy alternates between actions 00 and 1111 (potentially around the true threshold value). This gray area may be of particular concern to DMs because the policy in this region is not intuitive. For example, if a DM wishes to implement a threshold policy, the gray area would introduce ambiguity around where the best threshold lies (see Figure 2). The gray area is formally defined as follows:

This definition is useful when discussing the structure of estimated optimal policies and how the distribution of the gray area is impacted by state space size and quantity of available data to parameterize the MDP.

In summary, we have established the following results:

  • •

    A TPM P𝑃Pitalic_P having the DFR property implies that aggregated TPM Q𝑄Qitalic_Q will also have the DFR property (Proposition 1)

  • •

    There are sufficient conditions that prove that an aggregated TPM Q𝑄Qitalic_Q will have a threshold policy, assuming the unaggregated TPM P𝑃Pitalic_P also has a threshold policy (Proposition 2).

  • •

    An estimated MDP may not have a threshold policy due to statistical errors in estimated entries of the TPM, either P𝑃Pitalic_P or Q𝑄Qitalic_Q.

We have also defined a measure of policy ambiguity, given by the gray area. These results inform our computational study described in the next section.

3 Simulation Study of State Aggregation

In this section, we describe a simulation study used to computationally investigate the effects of state aggregation on the performance of MDP models. We consider an MDP which extends [2]’s discrete time Markov chain (DTMC) framework for a chronic disease progression by including a “wait” (0) and “intervention” (1) action. We simulate observations from the ground truth MDP to generate synthetic observation counts ni⁢jsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑗n_{ij}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then investigate how state aggregation affects the resulting policies generated by the estimated MDPs.

3.1 Properties of the MDPs in this study

Here, we state the important properties of the MDP structure. For the sake of space, we defer other details about the specific parameters and state aggregation function used in this study to Appendix A. First, [2] gives us the following:

Proposition 3

[2, Proposition 1] The TPM P0superscript𝑃0P^{0}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT described in Appendix A has the DFR property.

Given Proposition 3, the state aggregation procedure (Appendix A), and Proposition 2, the following can be proven:

Proposition 4

Every MDP (𝒮J,A,P,R)subscript𝒮𝐽𝐴𝑃𝑅(\mathcal{S}_{J},A,P,R)( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A , italic_P , italic_R ) and (𝒮K,A,QK,RQK)subscript𝒮𝐾𝐴subscript𝑄𝐾subscript𝑅subscript𝑄𝐾(\mathcal{S}_{K},A,Q_{K},R_{Q_{K}})( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) used in this study (detailed in Appendix A) is guaranteed to have a threshold policy that is optimal.

Proving that (𝒮J,𝒜,P,ℛ)subscript𝒮𝐽𝒜𝑃ℛ(\mathcal{S}_{J},\mathcal{A},P,\mathcal{R})( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , italic_P , caligraphic_R ) has an optimal threshold policy can be shown algebraically using the conditions in [3]. Consequently, Proposition 2 proves that each MDP (𝒮K,𝒜,QK,ℛQK)subscript𝒮𝐾𝒜subscript𝑄𝐾subscriptℛsubscript𝑄𝐾(\mathcal{S}_{K},\mathcal{A},Q_{K},\mathcal{R}_{Q_{K}})( caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in our study must have a threshold policy that is optimal. See Appendix D for the formal proof.

3.2 Simulation Procedures

We now describe the simulation procedure for the experiments. Our goal is to be able to compare the policies and remaining lifetimes estimates from estimated MDP models (those with TPM P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG or Q^Ksubscript^𝑄𝐾\hat{Q}_{K}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) to those of the ground truth MDP model (with TPM P𝑃Pitalic_P). There are four steps to the experiment:

  1. 1.

    Generating synthetic observational data from the ground truth TPM P0superscript𝑃0P^{0}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  2. 2.

3.2.1 Generating synthetic observational data on system progression

First, we generate synthetic observational data from the ground truth model by simulating a positive integer M𝑀Mitalic_M system trajectories through the states according to the ground truth TPM P0superscript𝑃0P^{0}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let hm,tsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡h_{m,t}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represent the state of system m𝑚mitalic_m in period t𝑡titalic_t for m=1,…,M𝑚1…𝑀m=1,\ldots,Mitalic_m = 1 , … , italic_M and t∈𝒯𝑡𝒯t\in\mathcal{T}italic_t ∈ caligraphic_T. We assume hm,0=J∀m=1,…,Mformulae-sequencesubscriptℎ𝑚0𝐽for-all𝑚1…𝑀h_{m,0}=J\quad\forall m=1,\ldots,Mitalic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_J ∀ italic_m = 1 , … , italic_M. Given the state of system m𝑚mitalic_m at time t𝑡titalic_t, hm,tsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡h_{m,t}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we determine the state at time t+1𝑡1t+1italic_t + 1 using Monte Carlo simulation. We sample a random variable, representing the next state, whose outcome is j𝑗jitalic_j with probability phm,t,j0subscriptsuperscript𝑝0subscriptℎ𝑚𝑡𝑗p^{0}_{h_{m,t},j}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This process is repeated until time t𝑡titalic_t such that hm,t=0subscriptℎ𝑚𝑡0h_{m,t}=0italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, and this trajectory is finished. Because P0superscript𝑃0P^{0}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the DFR property, each system entity is guaranteed to progress toward state 00 as t→∞→𝑡t\rightarrow\inftyitalic_t → ∞. In our experiments, we consider M∈{10,25,50,100,500,1000}𝑀1025501005001000M\in\{10,25,50,100,500,1000\}italic_M ∈ { 10 , 25 , 50 , 100 , 500 , 1000 }, and we set J=100𝐽100J=100italic_J = 100. We replicate the process of simulating M𝑀Mitalic_M system trajectories R𝑅Ritalic_R times, inputting the observations from all M𝑀Mitalic_M system trajectories of replication r𝑟ritalic_r into an observed count matrix 𝒩rsuperscript𝒩𝑟\mathcal{N}^{r}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for r=1,…,R𝑟1…𝑅r=1,\ldots,Ritalic_r = 1 , … , italic_R. We use R=100𝑅100R=100italic_R = 100 in our study.

3.2.2 Estimating transition probabilities and building the MDP model

Next, we use the synthetic observational data described above to construct MDP models with various levels of state aggregation. First, we solve the MDPs described by (𝒮J,𝒜,P^,ℛsubscript𝒮𝐽𝒜^𝑃ℛ\mathcal{S}_{J},\mathcal{A},\hat{P},\mathcal{R}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG , caligraphic_R) and (𝒮K,𝒜,Q^K,ℛQKsubscript𝒮𝐾𝒜subscript^𝑄𝐾subscriptℛsubscript𝑄𝐾\mathcal{S}_{K},\mathcal{A},\hat{Q}_{K},\mathcal{R}_{Q_{K}}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) to obtain optimal policies π^P^∗superscriptsubscript^𝜋^𝑃\hat{\pi}_{\hat{P}}^{*}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and π^Q^K∗superscriptsubscript^𝜋subscript^𝑄𝐾\hat{\pi}_{\hat{Q}_{K}}^{*}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively using the Python mdptoolbox module [8]. We denote the optimal policy of any arbitrary estimated model as π^∗superscript^𝜋\hat{\pi}^{*}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with no subscript. After these policies are generated, we investigate the optimal policy structure, different definitions of ambiguity (e.g., gray area, lack of threshold precision due to state aggregation, etc.), and how modeling decisions impact policy ambiguity and different value metrics of the policy.

First, we analyze the resulting policies to determine whether aggregation affects when intervention is recommended. By Proposition 4, the ground truth MDP described by (𝒮J,𝒜,P,ℛsubscript𝒮𝐽𝒜𝑃ℛ\mathcal{S}_{J},\mathcal{A},P,\mathcal{R}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , italic_P , caligraphic_R) has an optimal threshold policy, and we compute that the optimal threshold is TP=24subscript𝑇𝑃24T_{P}=24italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 24. Hence, if there were no statistical errors in the TPM, then 100% of the estimated policies in the R𝑅Ritalic_R replications would recommend intervention for h≤TPℎsubscript𝑇𝑃h\leq T_{P}italic_h ≤ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and waiting for h>TPℎsubscript𝑇𝑃h>T_{P}italic_h > italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, the absence of a sufficient number of observations when constructing an estimated TPM can lead to ambiguity in the threshold. This can be shown when different replications of an experiment for fixed M𝑀Mitalic_M and K𝐾Kitalic_K yield different optimal policies.

Next, we consider policy structure and ambiguity. By Proposition 4, the MDP described by (𝒮J,𝒜,P,ℛsubscript𝒮𝐽𝒜𝑃ℛ\mathcal{S}_{J},\mathcal{A},P,\mathcal{R}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_A , italic_P , caligraphic_R) has an optimal threshold policy. However, in general, the MDPs with TPMs P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG and Q^^𝑄\hat{Q}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG are not guaranteed to have threshold policies that are optimal, due to statistical error. We investigate whether these policies have a threshold structure and, if not, consider the size and empirical distribution of the gray area over the 100 replications.

Finally, we make value comparisons between the ground truth and the models estimated from data. One value metric is to quantify the expected losses in value incurred from estimation and/or aggregation, called expected regret. Let v⁢(π^∗,⋅)𝑣superscript^𝜋⋅v(\hat{\pi}^{*},\cdot)italic_v ( over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ⋅ ) denote the value of policy π^∗superscript^𝜋\hat{\pi}^{*}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT given by (2) where the second parameter is the TPM in which π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is evaluated, either P,P^𝑃^𝑃P,\hat{P}italic_P , over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG, or Q^^𝑄\hat{Q}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG. 3.3 Threshold policy assumption

It is possible that a modeler would create an MDP under the assumption that the MDP has a threshold policy, and he or she would only consider policies with a threshold structure. As an addendum to the aforementioned experiment, we will also compute and evaluate estimated optimal policies from estimated TPMs under the assumption of a threshold policy. We will denote the optimal policy under the threshold assumption as π¯∗superscript¯𝜋\bar{\pi}^{*}over¯ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let 𝔗𝔗\mathfrak{T}fraktur_T be the set of all threshold policies, and let v𝑣vitalic_v be the value function. Then, π¯∗=arg⁢maxπ∈𝔗⁡v⁢(π)superscript¯𝜋subscriptargmax𝜋𝔗𝑣𝜋\bar{\pi}^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{\pi\in\mathfrak{T}}\,v(\pi)over¯ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_max end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ∈ fraktur_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_π ), which can be solved by iterating over all possible π¯∈𝔗¯𝜋𝔗\bar{\pi}\in\mathfrak{T}over¯ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG ∈ fraktur_T. Note that πP∗=π¯P∗superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑃superscriptsubscript¯𝜋𝑃\pi_{P}^{*}=\bar{\pi}_{P}^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over¯ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since the true optimal policy is a threshold policy by Proposition 4.

4 Results

Here, we discuss the interpretability, correctness, and value of the estimated optimal policies computed from differently aggregated MDPs with TPMs estimated from data simulated from a single ground truth TPM (Appendix A).

4.1 Implications of state aggregation on intervention recommendations

We first consider how state aggregation and data availability impact the states in which intervention is recommended and at what frequency. Figure 3 shows the observed frequency of the intervention recommendation in each state as the availability of data and level of aggregation is varied.

First, we observe the differences in the frequency of the intervention recommendation in each state across R𝑅Ritalic_R replications when there is no threshold assumption (Figures 3(d) - 3(i)). We observe that as the state space size decreases, the intervention frequency plots approach an identical threshold policy for every replication. A similar trend occurs when we increase the number of available system trajectories, M𝑀Mitalic_M. As M𝑀Mitalic_M increases, these R𝑅Ritalic_R estimated policies begin to converge to a single threshold policy, although not necessarily the same threshold policy recommended by the true optimal policy πP∗superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑃\pi_{P}^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For example, take K=5𝐾5K=5italic_K = 5 in Figures 3(f) and 3(i). As the number of observed trajectories M𝑀Mitalic_M increases from M=50𝑀50M=50italic_M = 50 to M=500𝑀500M=500italic_M = 500, the intervention recommendations approach a threshold T^Q^5=20subscript^𝑇subscript^𝑄520\hat{T}_{\hat{Q}_{5}}=20over^ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 20.

While using a highly aggregated model may be useful for very low M𝑀Mitalic_M values, we see here that the lack of state precision can lead to early or late intervention. We compare this to Figures 3(d) and 3(g) which show K=J=100𝐾𝐽100K=J=100italic_K = italic_J = 100. As M𝑀Mitalic_M increases from 50505050 to 500500500500, the region of states for which there is disagreement about the optimal action shrinks from states 1,…,361…361,\ldots,361 , … , 36 to states 21,…,2521…2521,\ldots,2521 , … , 25. We expect that as M𝑀Mitalic_M approaches infinity, the plot would converge toward a threshold policy plot with threshold TPsubscript𝑇𝑃T_{P}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence, there is a high potential for policy improvement under 𝒮Jsubscript𝒮𝐽\mathcal{S}_{J}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as available data increases, whereas there is a limit to how much a policy under 𝒮Ksubscript𝒮𝐾\mathcal{S}_{K}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can improve due to the lack of state precision.

Now, we observe how the assumption of a threshold policy changes the variability in the 100 estimated optimal policies. Consider the top two rows of Figure 3, where the top row considers M=50𝑀50M=50italic_M = 50 system trajectories using a threshold policy assumption and the second row considers M=50𝑀50M=50italic_M = 50 system trajectories without the threshold assumption. We can observe that the threshold assumption leads to much better estimation of the true optimal policy in the K=100𝐾100K=100italic_K = 100 case, although there is no easily observable difference in the intervention recommendations for the K=20𝐾20K=20italic_K = 20 or K=5𝐾5K=5italic_K = 5 case. In Figure 3(a), the region of states for which there is disagreement about the optimal action is states 18,…,3318…3318,\ldots,3318 , … , 33, compared Figure 3(d) in which the ambiguous region consists of states 1,…,331…331,\ldots,331 , … , 33. For unaggregated state spaces, the threshold assumption appears to mitigate the impacts of statistical uncertainty in the lower states, which tend to have fewer observations.

4.2 Implications of state aggregation on the distribution of the gray area

Now, we consider the effect of state aggregation on the empirical distributions of the intervene-gray area and gray area-wait thresholds in the estimated optimal policies obtained from 100 replications of the experiment. In Figure 4, we plot the frequency of the locations of Λ0subscriptΛ0\Lambda_{0}roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the critical state above which π^∗⁢(h)=0superscript^𝜋ℎ0\hat{\pi}^{*}(h)=0over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) = 0) and Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1}roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the critical state below which π^∗⁢(h)=1superscript^𝜋ℎ1\hat{\pi}^{*}(h)=1over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) = 1). Note that the state space is truncated at state 50 since there is no ambiguity in the optimal policy after that point. Furthermore, the “spikes” that we observe for the subplots where K<100𝐾100K<100italic_K < 100 are due to the fact that a threshold can only exist at specific states for aggregated models (e.g., for K=10, our threshold can only exist at states that are multiples of 10).

The gray area in Figure 4 can be thought of as the space between the red and blue distributions representing Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1}roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Λ0subscriptΛ0\Lambda_{0}roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. From this figure, we see that as the number of system trajectories increases, the distributions of Λ1subscriptΛ1\Lambda_{1}roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Λ0subscriptΛ0\Lambda_{0}roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approach each other (i.e., the gray area shrinks). The same convergence occurs as the number of states in the state space decreases. For K=20𝐾20K=20italic_K = 20 and K=10𝐾10K=10italic_K = 10, we observe a very tight overlap in the distribution of the two thresholds, which lends the assumption that many of the 100 replications yield a threshold policy for these state spaces. However, the leftward bias we observe for low values of M𝑀Mitalic_M likely indicates that the computed threshold, T^Q^subscript^𝑇^𝑄\hat{T}_{\hat{Q}}over^ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is often less than the true optimal threshold, TPsubscript𝑇𝑃T_{P}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Another important observation from Figure 4 is how quickly the two empirical threshold distributions obtained from the 100 replications converge. We see that for K=50𝐾50K=50italic_K = 50, the two distributions shift from almost complete separation to a high area of intersection between M=10𝑀10M=10italic_M = 10 and M=25𝑀25M=25italic_M = 25. This could be explained by the finding from [2] in showing that statistical error decreases quickly even with small increases in M𝑀Mitalic_M. Hence, the optimal policies using high values of K𝐾Kitalic_K (i.e., a larger, less aggregated state space) will show quicker reductions in the ambiguous gray area than those with low values of K𝐾Kitalic_K (i.e., a smaller, more aggregated state space) with only small increases in M𝑀Mitalic_M.

4.3 Implications of state aggregation on remaining system lifetime estimates

In this subsection, we investigate the impacts of state aggregation and data availability on the expected regret, defined in (8). Figure 5 shows how the empirical distribution of expected regret across the 100 replications changes as the number of system trajectories increases. The sample mean of the expected regret for each model is represented by a dot.

First, consider Figures 5(a) and 5(c). We note a rough “U”-shaped curve in the sample mean of the expected regret as the number of aggregated states decreases. For experiments without a threshold policy assumption, we observe some moderate level of state aggregation K𝐾Kitalic_K which minimizes the mean observed expected regret for a given number of system trajectories available, M𝑀Mitalic_M.

Figures 5(a) and 5(c) show how the empirical distribution of expected regret across the 100 replications changes as the number of system trajectories increases. The sample mean of the expected regret for each model is represented by a dot. In both Figures 5(a) and 5(c), we note a rough “U”-shaped curve in the sample mean of the expected regret as the number of aggregated states decreases. In each case, we observe some moderate level of state aggregation (in these cases, both K=25𝐾25K=25italic_K = 25) that minimizes the mean observed expected regret for a given number of system trajectories available, M𝑀Mitalic_M.

As we might expect, as the number of observed trajectories M𝑀Mitalic_M increases, the expected regret for a given model with fixed K𝐾Kitalic_K either decreases or remains constant due to more accurate estimates of the TPM. However, the rate at which the expected regret for each model decreases is not the same for each level of aggregation. From Figure 5(a) to Figure 5(c), we see that the expected regret for the models defined by K=10𝐾10K=10italic_K = 10 remain relatively unchanged as M𝑀Mitalic_M increases (note that y-axis scales differ on each row); the mean expected regret decreases from approximately 505 months per thousand system trajectories to approximately 426 months per thousand system trajectories, about a 15.6% decrease. On the other hand, P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG, defined by K=100𝐾100K=100italic_K = 100, decreases comparatively rapidly as M𝑀Mitalic_M increases. The mean expected regret for K=100𝐾100K=100italic_K = 100 decreases from approximately 948 months per thousand system trajectories to approximately 218 life months per thousand system trajectories, which is about a 77% decrease. For reference, the “never intervene” policy yields an expected regret of over 25,0002500025,00025 , 000 months per thousand system entities, which shows that intervention vastly improves the life of the system entity in this scenario and demonstrates the scale of improvements from moderate aggregation.

Based on Figures 5(a) and 5(c), one might conjecture that the lack of precision in highly aggregated models (e.g., Q^10subscript^𝑄10\hat{Q}_{10}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) will lead to underperformance relative to more finely aggregated models (e.g., P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG), especially when the number of observed trajectories, M, is large. However, in some cases, the impact of the lack of precision depends on the value of TPsubscript𝑇𝑃T_{P}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its location relative to the upper limit cutoff states in 𝒮Jsubscript𝒮𝐽\mathcal{S}_{J}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each aggregated state h∈𝒮Kℎsubscript𝒮𝐾h\in\mathcal{S}_{K}italic_h ∈ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For example, if J=100𝐽100J=100italic_J = 100 and K=5𝐾5K=5italic_K = 5, the cutoff states would be {20,40,60,80,100}20406080100\{20,40,60,80,100\}{ 20 , 40 , 60 , 80 , 100 }. Suppose our model had TP=20subscript𝑇𝑃20T_{P}=20italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 20 instead of TP=24subscript𝑇𝑃24T_{P}=24italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 24. Because 20202020 is a cutoff state for 𝒮5subscript𝒮5\mathcal{S}_{5}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there will be no early or late intervention when a threshold policy is obtained for K=5𝐾5K=5italic_K = 5. Hence, our model with K=5𝐾5K=5italic_K = 5 will likely attain 00 regret by a relatively low M𝑀Mitalic_M value, in which case P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG can, at best, have an equal expected regret. Deviations from the aforementioned U-curve with regard to the sample mean of the expected regret can also be partially attributed to the relationship between TPsubscript𝑇𝑃T_{P}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and state cutoffs. See Appendix C for an example of this.

Next, we consider how the addition of a threshold policy assumption alters the expected regret. The most noticeable difference between Figures 5(a) and 5(c) and Figures 5(b) and 5(d) is that the expected regret for K=100𝐾100K=100italic_K = 100 and K=50𝐾50K=50italic_K = 50 is substantially lower when we assume a threshold policy. In 5(b), the mean expected regret for K=100𝐾100K=100italic_K = 100 is approximately 285 months, whereas in 5(d), the mean expected regret is approximately 88 months. Both values are substantially lower than the mean expected regrets observed in the case where a threshold policy is not assumed (Figures 5(a) and 5(c)), which have expected regrets of approximately 948 and 218 months, respectively. This result is intuitive for two reasons. First, the true optimal policy is also a threshold policy, so this assumption does not lead to an inherent disadvantage when modeling. Second, the main drawback of large state spaces is the relatively low number of system observations to draw from in each state. By forcing the estimated optimal policy to have a threshold structure, we are not simply choosing which action to take in which state, we are choosing the threshold location. This suggests that threshold policies tend to be robust against errors in entries p^h⁢h′subscript^𝑝ℎsuperscriptℎ′\hat{p}_{hh^{\prime}}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG. Hence, state aggregation loses its advantage when we already employ the threshold policy assumption. For highly aggregated models, assuming a threshold policy has a lesser effect on decreasing regret. In fact, we achieve near-identical results for K=10𝐾10K=10italic_K = 10 in Figures 5(a) and 5(b) and Figures 5(c) and 5(d).

Lastly, we examine the difference between the expected remaining life months using the optimal policy π^∗superscript^𝜋\hat{\pi}^{*}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT versus the no-intervention policy π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Figure 6 shows the 95%percent9595\%95 % confidence interval for the estimated remaining life months for each state according to the DM (i.e., without access to the ground truth), given by v⁢(π0,Q^K)𝑣subscript𝜋0subscript^𝑄𝐾v(\pi_{0},\hat{Q}_{K})italic_v ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and v⁢(π^Q^K∗⁢Q^K)𝑣superscriptsubscript^𝜋subscript^𝑄𝐾subscript^𝑄𝐾v(\hat{\pi}_{\hat{Q}_{K}}^{*}\hat{Q}_{K})italic_v ( over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

We first observe that the difference between the sample means of v⁢(π^Q^K∗,Q^K)𝑣superscriptsubscript^𝜋subscript^𝑄𝐾subscript^𝑄𝐾v(\hat{\pi}_{\hat{Q}_{K}}^{*},\hat{Q}_{K})italic_v ( over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and v⁢(π0,Q^K)𝑣subscript𝜋0subscript^𝑄𝐾v(\pi_{0},\hat{Q}_{K})italic_v ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) at h=100ℎ100h=100italic_h = 100 increases as K𝐾Kitalic_K decreases. Secondly, we note some biases in the Q^^𝑄\hat{Q}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG estimates. One such bias is that for aggregated policies in lower states, the no-intervention policy often overestimates the expected remaining lifetime. Furthermore, due to the sharper increase of the optimal value function for low states, the estimated optimal value function for aggregated models 6(c) and 6(d) will only closely approximate the true optimal value for the states near the midpoint of the aggregated state. Once the value function becomes more level at approximately state 20, the estimated expected remaining lifetime under the estimated optimal policy is a closer estimate of the true expected remaining lifetime, although estimated remaining lifetime in higher states are slightly underestimated.

5 Conclusion

In this study, we show that estimated MDP models with moderately aggregated state spaces can generate policies that lead to less decision ambiguity and lower expected regret than coarsely or finely aggregated models. This finding differs from the recommendation from [2] that DTMC models of disease prognosis under no treatment should use little to no state aggregation. We find that, even for 1000100010001000 observations, the mean expected regret for taking the optimal policy estimated from a model using the full 100-state state space (i.e., using P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG) was still higher than those using aggregated TPMs Q^25subscript^𝑄25\hat{Q}_{25}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 25 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Q^50subscript^𝑄50\hat{Q}_{50}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This finding reveals that minimizing error in the TPM does not necessarily translate to minimizing the expected regret of the MDP model.

Furthermore, we find that for a low number of available system trajectories, moderately aggregated MDPs are more likely to closely approximate the true threshold policy and eliminate some of the ambiguity from the gray area. However, it is still possible to over-aggregate a state space, where precision losses lead to poor estimation of the threshold. Overall, one of the key problems with choosing the most desirable state space to model the system’s progression with a threshold policy is the “luck” of where that true unknown threshold TPsubscript𝑇𝑃T_{P}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT lies on the aggregated state space. Hence, the generalization that the full model’s estimated TPM will lead to lower regret than an aggregated model’s estimated TPM as the number of observed system trajectories increases is not necessarily true. Future work might consider how to estimate this threshold location from limited data.

Our finding that moderately aggregated TPMs can perform better with regard to threshold estimation and expected regret does not hold when the estimated optimal policy is required to be a threshold policy. When this assumption is made, P^^𝑃\hat{P}over^ start_ARG italic_P end_ARG often leads to a lower mean expected regret in our computational study than Q^Ksubscript^𝑄𝐾\hat{Q}_{K}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for K<100𝐾100K<100italic_K < 100. Because the true optimal policy is a threshold policy, we incur no disadvantage by making this assumption. Furthermore, requiring a threshold policy protects against individual outlier point estimates for P0superscript𝑃0P^{0}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, particularly for low values of hℎhitalic_h. The natural question is whether or not it makes sense to assume a threshold policy in a general setting where we are unsure of the true optimal policy structure. The answer to this question would depend on the system being modeled and the preferences of the DMs. For example, if the “system” was a patient being treated for a chronic disease, threshold policies are commonly assumed. From a clinician perspective, threshold policies are intuitive and easier to implement than non-threshold policies. Hence, a threshold policy assumption may be preferable, even if the underlying disease progression model would not lead to a threshold policy that is optimal. For other systems, a threshold policy may not be an advantageous assumption.

Our work is not without limitations. First, we consider a hypothetical deteriorating Markov process from literature [2]. The use of hypothetical models has been used before to enable comparisons to the “ground truth” optimal policy and remaining lifetime estimates that would not be available otherwise [2, 9]. However, the model used was one of many possible models that could be considered with the desired properties specified in §1.2. Future work could consider other TPM designs using the framework from [2] or consider different structures of TPMs altogether, such as models in which the system can never improve. These different structures may yield different results in terms of the utility of state aggregation.

Our analysis motivates opportunities for future research. Future work could investigate methods for comparing different state space designs in the absence of a ground truth model. Our work suggests that the choice of state space can indeed influence the quality of the resulting recommendations and remaining system life estimates. A rigorous approach to comparing different potential state space designs when there is no ground truth model could be beneficial to modelers. Future work could also consider the influence of censored observational data (e.g., sparsity in transitions between high-health and low-health states in chronic disease models) on state space design. Furthermore, this article focused on optimal stopping-time models, so there is an opportunity to investigate more complex action spaces.

Appendix A Detailed description of the MDP used in the simulation study

We choose to use monthly decision epochs, and, as such, use a standard discount rate α=0.9975𝛼0.9975\alpha=0.9975italic_α = 0.9975. The full, unaggregated state space is given by 𝒮J={0,1,2,…,J−1,J,J+1}subscript𝒮𝐽012…𝐽1𝐽𝐽1\mathcal{S}_{J}=\{0,1,2,\ldots,J-1,J,J+1\}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { 0 , 1 , 2 , … , italic_J - 1 , italic_J , italic_J + 1 }, where states 00 and J+1𝐽1J+1italic_J + 1 are absorbing, and states 1,2,3,…,J123…𝐽1,2,3,\ldots,J1 , 2 , 3 , … , italic_J are in increasing order of “goodness” (i.e., state x+1𝑥1x+1italic_x + 1 is preferred to state x𝑥xitalic_x). The DM wishes to avoid the absorbing 00 “death” state (e.g., equipment is irreparably damaged or a patient dies before treatment is initiated), and state J+1𝐽1J+1italic_J + 1 can be considered an absorbing “post-intervention” state (i.e., the engine in a car is replaced, or a patient with kidney disease undergoes a kidney transplant). Like [2], we set J=100𝐽100J=100italic_J = 100 for all of our simulations. Appendix B Lumping function

In this subsection, we introduce the lumping function s:𝒮J↦𝒮K:𝑠maps-tosubscript𝒮𝐽subscript𝒮𝐾s:\mathcal{S}_{J}\mapsto\mathcal{S}_{K}italic_s : caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ↦ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Appendix C Alternative TPM Design Result

In this Appendix, we give an example of an MDP for which lumping error has minor effects on regret. This is an example of a “lucky” scenario when TPsubscript𝑇𝑃T_{P}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is extremely close to the maximum value of Lhsubscript𝐿ℎL_{h}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for h=s⁢(TP)ℎ𝑠subscript𝑇𝑃h=s(T_{P})italic_h = italic_s ( italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In Figure 7, we do not see the U-shaped curve, but rather see that the minimum mean expected regret is given by K=5𝐾5K=5italic_K = 5.
